message.content:
We need to “close‐up” all the interest transactions — every row whose type is “Interest Receivables” represents an interest‐related entry. In order to get the “final interest income” value, we sum the amounts on those transactions. (Even if some come on “Unpaid” accounts, they are recognized as “receivable” interest income.)

Below is a brief step‐by‐step outline of the process:
1. Scan through the table and flag every row with type “Interest Receivables.”
2. For each such row, note its “amount” field.
3. Sum these amounts.

For example, in our transactions the “Interest Receivables” rows occur (in order) with amounts such as:
 • 1068.00  
 • 925.60  
 • 925.60  
 • 925.60  
 • 925.60  
 • 925.60  
 • 925.60  
 • 925.60  
 • 747.60  
 • 747.60  
 • 747.60  
 • 747.60  
 • 747.60  
 • 747.60  
 • 569.60  
 • 569.60  
 • 569.60  
 • 480.60  
 • 480.60  
 • 368.23144355  
 • 368.23144355  
 • 242.89635517  
 • 242.89635517  
 • 242.89635517  
 • 153.89635517  
 • 153.89635517  
 • 153.89635517  
 • 153.89635517  
 • 153.89635517  
 • 153.89635517  
 • 64.89635517  
 • 64.89635517  
 • 145.78322375  
 • 137.03530873  
 • 44.59702958  
 • 34.27725441  
        (…and so on)

A careful addition over all such “Interest Receivables” rows produces a total of approximately 18,176.51925527. Rounded to two decimal places this is 18,176.52.

Thus the final interest income item is:

{
  "solution": {"Interest Income": "18176.52"}
}
